author: keithmattix

comment_body:
We remain limited by the events that are emitted from the GitHub API, which unfortunately do not include any relating to discussions.

We would have to do some sort of search or export of the discussions to be able to include them, and as with everything, apply some discretion: a thread answered immediately and authoritatively is "worth more" than a thread with 20 different back-and-forth messages and no resolution.

I'm going to close this as "not feasible" at this point, and we can include this thinking in the steering formula calculation we are now obliged to do.

author: linsun

comment_body:
Subgroups have maintainer access to the parent group too.. so if the goal is to block someones access to "networking", subgroup would not work.

IMO fewer groups is easier to maintain and grok. A networking maintainer doesn't need to be an expert on all things "networking" in Istio -- and I don't any current maintainers are given the breadth of Istio. Part of the responsibilities of a maintainer is not just to approve PRs, but also know when _not_ to approve PRs. For example, if a Maintainer was a CNI pro but had no other expertise (which is not the case for Ben, IMO, just an example), I would simply expect them to not approve PRs outside of CNI.

Note the "pilot" subgroup is a bit different scenario. That was about making a higher bar for a critical code portion. This CNI group discussion is more like a side-group, not sub-group. Generally our groups are all bucketed under WGs, though, which makes the not possible in GitHub. As noted above though, I don't think we need to anyways.

author: craigbox

comment_body: @craigbox I don't have a direct model available for open source yet. But we can train one, and there's also the technology or platform to consider using, and there's the cost involved when we have to integrate the model to call the APIs, and I haven't figured out how to do all that yet.
author: rootsongjc
terrchen

comment_body:
What Jimmy is proposing is effectively training a transformer model on the Istio and Envoy documentation, Q&A etc, and then using that to answer _user_ questions in the first instance.

Some GitHub data might be useful in this, but I think that is more likely to trend towards _developer_ questions/answers.
author: craigbox

comment_body:
I'm actually interested in generating embeddings that can support multiple personas (customers, developers, managers, executives, etc.) so what Jimmy is proposing does interest me, but I can see how including more development related data, can increase complexity.  

I'm not sure what stage things are at, but I am very interested in learning more about your findings and knowing what sources (documents, questions, etc.) you are planning on training on.
author: terrchen

comment_body: @terrchen I haven't started yet. Your tool is very useful for showing the contribution data but do you have any bot to answer questions in the the GIthub issue or discussions?
author: rootsongjc

comment_body:
@rootsongjc Not yet.  The goal is to get to a point where I can create agents/bots to answer questions and to perform tasks for maintainers, developers, team leads, etc.

The conclusion that I've come to is, in order to create a useful automated Q and A system, you'll need an easy way to do the following:

1) Classify and clean data.
2) Generate Q and A pairs.  
3) Review and iterate on generated Q and A pairs

The part that I will be tackling in the near future is creating a system to classify and clean data, which is the most critical, since garbage in = garbage out.  Once you have clean data (with good metadata), generating Q and A pairs should be pretty straight forward as you can use LLMs to generate them. 

If you have a system or thoughts on how to clean/organize the data, I'd be interested to hear them.  I'm currently planning on creating a system that will leverage LLM to help classify and prep data.

comment_body: Hey @howardjohn @SAMZONG I discovered a Quick Fix for it. I have made a directory called members, where you can add your name randomly. Now the script sorts the YAML and makes a copy of the ```tempname.yaml``` to generate updated ```members.yaml```.

I don't think we want to have people enter their names in multiple places. This leads to potential issues with changes overriding others or changes being lost. Maybe you have a script to grab the section from the member.yaml, sort it and put it back.

comment_body:
I never seen the slack invite working. Does it really allow people to join? 

Such a good technology but it seems everyone is busy in making things in closed walls. I am very new to Istio; but not new to the  kubernets and containerisation. I felt it very hard to interact within Istio community. There are stackoverflow or Istio own forums where more than 70% threads are not answered. This doesn’t reflect good to me; no doubt you have good product but if you fail to build user base then I’m sorry you don’t have great future and people will turn somewhere else. Be serious about the users and their queries as you are developing the technology for next generation.
author: sybadm

comment_body: Can you try it now
author: howardjohn

comment_body:
Hi @ksudate and @sybadm: I'm sorry for the delay in getting this fixed.  We're in "flux" at the moment as we move from Google infrastructure to CNCF infrastructure.  When I worked at Google I would have fixed this immediately :)

The Slack thing we run is a workaround because their software isn't made for communities like this, but it's the software that everyone in the CNCF seems to use. There's no way to issue invites from Slack itself, so we have to generate these tokens which are valid for a few hundred users.  When those are all used up, we have to generate a new URL.

It's definitely working now!

As for questions and answers on Stack Overflow and Discuss, I do also see there's a lot of questions not being answered. That's a challenge when there are so many vendors.  One thing that we're going to try and do in the Steering committee this term is encourage our community to help answer user questions.   Developers are busy developing and don't tend to pay as much attention as they do early in the life of a project.

(@howardjohn is excluded from this critique, as not only has he replied on this thread, but also replies to many Slack threads)
author: craigbox

comment_body:
Awesome! Thanks for the quick response. This is how it should be. I’m very happy to support the community wherever I can.

tx

author: linsun

comment_body:
Its part of
https://istio.io/latest/docs/reference/config/istio.mesh.v1alpha1/#MeshConfig

On Fri, Oct 14, 2022 at 5:26 AM That Guy at Github ***@***.***>
wrote:

> Hi, we have found that the default policy about failing envoy requests is
> to retry twice after a given timeout period, as its well detailed on the
> documentation here
> https://istio.io/latest/docs/concepts/traffic-management/#retries.
>
> The default retry behavior for HTTP requests is to retry twice before returning the error.
>
> We were trying to disable it globally everywhere because particularly for
> us, it's introducing some inconsistencies on HTTP POST operations that
> alter the nature of the object, generating some inconsistency issues.
>
> We were unable to find a way to disable HTTP connection retries globally
> in a way that does not imply creating VirtualService on a per-service
> basis, which will add a lot of complexity for us.
>
> Can you help us confirm that there is no way to instruct Istio not to
> perform any kind of connection retries at HTTP globally?
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/istio/community/issues/838>, or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAEYGXKNO75JRK4N6TSMEJDWDFGPJANCNFSM6AAAAAARFGFSKY>
> .
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.Message
> ID: ***@***.***>
>

author: thatguyatgithub

comment_body:
A couple of additional comments and @therealmitchconnors can correct if needed.

https://github.com/istio/community/blob/master/ROLES.md?plain=1#L234-L236 is the section of the community docs that discuss this. 

The `extended period of time` is not defined, but for this issue is 1 yr. Note that the inactive tab on the dashboard is 90 days for maintainers. If you make a contribution, the clock starts over. I think just replying to this issue would be enough.

comment_body:
> The Helm charts used in this guide are the same underlying charts used when installing Istio via [Istioctl](https://istio.io/latest/docs/setup/install/istioctl/) or the [Operator](https://istio.io/latest/docs/setup/install/operator/).

comment_body: The method for configuring arbitrary settings in Envoy is EnvoyFilter; I don't believe we plan to expose any other method.  We're instead working on our own APIs like the Telemetry API.
author: craigbox

comment_body: Thanks for the issue @gauravdewat . Istio/community is for organizational issues, charters, etc - you can use http://github.com/istio/istio for the main product issue tracker. That being said, this is working as intended - CRDs essentially act as a database and removing CRDs is equivilent to doing `rm -rf /` on that database. You can follow https://istio.io/latest/docs/setup/install/operator/#uninstall for a _full_ removal. Cheers
author: howardjohn
howardjohn

comment_body: I understand this is expected, as you declare `my-app.default` as an endpoint, and set the se dns type, iun envoy xds, `my-app.default`  is an dns type cluster, so when the lb algorithm selected it, it will resolve it to the clusterIP of the local cluster where the caller resides. Then the traffic goes through as k8s expects.
author: hzxuzhonghu

comment_body: @hzxuzhonghu hmm.. yah. Then how can I reach the service in the other cluster with the same custom host name `my-app.service.consul`? In some examples I always see things like `my-app.global`, I wonder if that is some sort of keyword or I am just missing something (https://istio.io/latest/blog/2020/multi-cluster-mesh-automation/)
author: romanlehner

comment_body:
What is `<my-aws-lb>.elb.amazonaws.com`? 

I think you can add cluster b service entrance as an endpoint of se
author: hzxuzhonghu

comment_body:
that is the `east west gateway` load balancer for multicluster communication. I have it from this example here: https://istio.io/latest/blog/2020/multi-cluster-mesh-automation/.  But when the request hits the load balancer I get this error:
```
[2021-10-22T12:49:16.399Z] "- - -" 0 NR filter_chain_not_found - "-" 0 0 0 - "-" "-" "-" "-" "-" - - 100.96.43.64:15443 100.96.36.28:50136 - -
```

So I guess there is not enough information for the request to get routed.
author: romanlehner

comment_body:
I understand. I guess the `NR` error is because the default gateway requires *.local, you can try change it

```
apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1alpha3
kind: Gateway
metadata:
  name: cross-network-gateway
spec:
  selector:
    istio: eastwestgateway
  servers:
    - port:
        number: 15443
        name: tls
        protocol: TLS
      tls:
        mode: AUTO_PASSTHROUGH
      hosts:
        - "*.local"
```
author: hzxuzhonghu

comment_body:
Ah that's a good hint. Although I already configured it they way you present it. But that makes me wonder if I have to add:

```yaml
...
hosts:
  - "*.local"
  - "*.service.consul"
  ```
  
  And then in the other cluster `*.service.consul` has to resolve somehow as well. Maybe with another service entry?
author: romanlehner

comment_body: @hzxuzhonghu thank you for your support so far. I think I will close this issue, as it is not really an issue, but me not understanding how to configure a hostname with service entry that connects across clusters. I will create another topic restating my request.

comment_body: Yeah Istio can do this. Take a look at https://istio.io/latest/docs/tasks/observability/metrics/using-istio-dashboard/

[root@k8s-master1 ~]# kubectl logs -n istio-system istiod-79dd646bcd-dqsm4 -f

2021-06-10T01:02:20.943082Z     warn    serverca        Authentication failed for 10.244.159.129:53156: Authenticator ClientCertAuthenticator at index 0 got error: no verified chain is found. Authenticator KubeJWTAuthenticator at index 1 got error: failed to validate the JWT from cluster "Kubernetes": the service account authentication returns an error: [invalid bearer token, square/go-jose: error in cryptographic primitive].
author: cc20110101

comment_body:
Hi, I am facing the exact same issue.

istio 1.11.4
k8s 1.20.7

My istio proxy sidecars are generating those errors in the original post, and their readiness probe is constantly failing. My istiod logs are also showing the same "[invalid bearer token, square/go-jose: error in cryptographic primitive]" errors for pods that have issues.

I notice that the moment I do a rollout restart of the istiod deployment, the proxy sidecar will recover within seconds, with the readiness passing health check. Checking the sidecar logs will show that it generated new workload certificate, detected the root cert has changed and start rotating the root cert.

struggling with this for a couple of days now.
